title: Why does one put 2 dots after every word in a sentence? - Quora

response.answer_text: Good style: Why does one put two dots after every word in a sentence? Questionable style: Why does one put 2 dots after every word in a sentence? The answer: One^^^^^doesn’t. It’s^^^^^five^^^^^circumflex^^^^^marks. Exception: This does not apply to Japanese. For example: この時計を一万円で買いました。 kono tokei o ichi man en de kaimasita “I bought this watch for 10,000 yen.” You see? No spaces, hence no place for circumflex marks! By the way, 10,000 is a large number, so there is no objection on stylistic grounds in this case. Theological question: Can God put infinitely many circumflex marks after each word in a sentence? Hypothetical practical question: If God can put infinitely many circumflex marks after each word in a sentence and elects to do so, can one get through the entire sentence before lunch? Real-life question: What are you talking about?

That.. would.. look.. like.. this. It would also be wrong. There is no grammatically correct reason for one to do that, in English. (I cannot speak for what practices may occur in other languages.) If one is writing informally, not for any academic or business purpose, and wished to indicate a person speaking slowly, with pauses between each word, then one might choose to use two periods after each word. The standard practice, still informal but slightly more acceptable, for this kind of indication would be to use three periods after each word, a form of punctuation known as an ‘ellipsis.’ There are various schools of thought as to exactly how to compose an ellipsis. Here are some examples: Ellipsis . . .Ellipsis. . .Ellipsis …Ellipsis… For the sake of taking up a tiny bit less space, I prefer the last one. Using that example, the original sentence of this answer would look like: That… would… look… like… this.
